questions.q: Which task can ONLY be performed by the RN?
options: Patient teaching about a new medication
questions.rationale: Teaching requires nursing judgment and assessment of understanding — it cannot be delegated to UAPs or LPNs.

questions.q: An LPN can perform which task?
questions.rationale: LPNs can administer PO, IM, and SQ medications; they cannot do initial assessments, teaching, or IV push meds.

questions.q: Which task is appropriate for a UAP?
questions.rationale: I&O measurement is a routine task that does not require nursing judgment and is appropriate for UAPs.

questions.q: Who is ultimately accountable for a delegated task?
questions.rationale: The RN who delegates retains accountability; delegation transfers the task, not the responsibility.

questions.q: A nurse finds 3 patients need care. Who is seen FIRST?
questions.rationale: Airway obstruction is immediately life-threatening; ABC prioritization places airway above all other concerns.

questions.q: A patient is anxious AND has labored breathing. The nurse should FIRST:
questions.rationale: Physiologic needs (breathing) take priority over psychosocial needs (anxiety) per Maslow's hierarchy.

questions.q: Which patient should the nurse see FIRST?
options: COPD patient with O2 sat of 89%
Post-op patient with new onset confusion
questions.rationale: New onset confusion is an acute change requiring immediate assessment; the others are chronic/expected findings.

questions.q: Which patient should be assigned to the new graduate nurse?
options: Stable chronic heart failure on telemetry
questions.rationale: The stable CHF patient is most predictable; complex/unstable patients require experienced nursing judgment.

questions.q: The MOST effective way to prevent infection transmission is:
questions.rationale: Hand hygiene (washing or alcohol-based rub) is the single most effective measure to break the chain of infection.

questions.q: Standard Precautions apply to which patients?
questions.rationale: Standard Precautions are universal — applied to every patient encounter regardless of known or suspected infection status.

questions.q: Which precaution requires an N95 respirator?
questions.rationale: Airborne precautions require N95 respirators because particles remain suspended in air and travel long distances.

questions.q: Droplet precautions require the nurse to wear:
questions.rationale: A surgical mask protects against large respiratory droplets that travel up to 3 feet before falling.

questions.q: A patient with C. diff requires which hand hygiene method?
questions.rationale: C. diff spores are NOT killed by alcohol-based hand rubs; only soap and water with friction removes them.

questions.q: The nurse reaches across a sterile field. The field is now:
options: Only the touched area is contaminated
questions.rationale: Reaching across a sterile field breaks the barrier; the entire field is considered contaminated and must be replaced.

questions.q: The nurse's role in informed consent is to:
questions.rationale: The nurse witnesses that the patient signed voluntarily and appeared to understand; the physician explains the procedure.

questions.q: How often should restrained extremities be released for ROM?
questions.rationale: Restraints must be released every 2 hours for ROM exercises, toileting, nutrition, and circulation checks.

questions.q: When calling the physician about a patient change, the nurse should use:
questions.rationale: SBAR provides a structured, concise communication framework that ensures critical information is relayed efficiently.

questions.q: After a medication error, the nurse should NOT:
options: Document objective findings in the chart
Write 'incident report filed' in the chart
questions.rationale: Never reference the incident report in the patient chart; it is a quality improvement document and is legally discoverable if referenced.

questions.q: Which patient should the nurse assess FIRST?
options: Patient 2 days post-op with pain of 4/10
Patient with COPD and SpO2 of 90%
Patient with a new tracheostomy and labored breathing
questions.rationale: A new tracheostomy with labored breathing is an acute airway emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.q: To correct a charting error, the nurse should:
options: Draw a single line through it and initial
Tear out the page and redo it
Leave it and add a sticky note
questions.rationale: A single line through the error, initialed and dated, preserves the original entry while indicating the correction.
